title: Conquering Mount Rainier: A Beginner's Guide to Mountaineering
author: You
excerpt: My first major mountaineering expedition - lessons learned, gear tips, and why starting at 3am is actually a good idea...
content:
After months of training and planning, I finally summited Mount Rainier! Here's everything I learned:

**Training**: Started 6 months out with stair climbing (with weighted pack), cardio, and strength training. The altitude hit harder than expected!

**Gear Essentials**: Crampons, ice axe, and layering system were crucial. Rented mountaineering boots - glad I tested them first.

**The Climb**: We started at midnight from Camp Muir. The headlamp-lit glacier was surreal. Sunrise from 14,000 feet? Absolutely magical.

**Tips for First-Timers**:
- Hire a guide service (I used RMI)
- Train at altitude if possible  
- Don't underestimate the mental challenge
- Bring twice as many snacks as you think you need

Would I do it again? Absolutely!

title: Essential Gear for Your First Multi-Day Hike
author: You
excerpt: From backpack to sleeping bag - here's what actually matters when you're carrying your home on your back...
content:
Planning your first multi-day hike? Here's my tried-and-true gear list:

**The Big 3:**
1. **Backpack** (40-65L): Osprey Aura 65 - comfortable, durable
2. **Shelter**: REI Quarter Dome 2 - lightweight, easy setup
3. **Sleeping System**: 20°F down bag + inflatable pad

**Kitchen**:
- Jetboil stove (so fast!)
- Titanium spork
- Dehydrated meals (Mountain House is tasty)

**Clothing**:
- Merino wool base layers (worth the investment)
- Puffy jacket (Patagonia Nano Puff)
- Rain shell and pants (don't cheap out here)

**Don't Forget**:
- First aid kit
- Water filter (Sawyer Squeeze)
- Headlamp + extra batteries
- Bear canister (if required)

**My Biggest Lesson**: You don't need the most expensive gear, but do invest in comfort (pack fit, sleeping pad, good socks).

title: Angels Landing: How to Conquer Your Fear of Heights
author: You
excerpt: Terrified of heights? Me too. Here's how I made it up (and down) Angels Landing's famous chain section...
content:
Full disclosure: I'm afraid of heights. So why did I attempt Angels Landing?

**Mental Prep**:
- Watched videos (helps to know what to expect)
- Reminded myself: thousands do this safely every year
- Went with an experienced friend

**The Reality**:
The chain section is 0.5 miles of exposed climbing. It's narrow, it's steep, and yes, it's scary. But:
- The chains are VERY secure
- There's always a handhold
- You can take it at your own pace
- People are super supportive

**My Strategy**:
1. Started at 6am to avoid crowds and heat
2. Focused on the next chain, not the drop
3. Took breaks at wider sections
4. Three-point contact always
5. Going DOWN was actually easier!

**Was It Worth It?**
Absolutely. The views are incredible, and I'm so proud I pushed through my fear. Start early, take your time, and you've got this!

title: Planning Your First Thru-Hike: Tour du Mont Blanc Prep
author: You
excerpt: 11 days, 170km, 3 countries - here's how I'm preparing for the TMB...
content:
I'm planning the Tour du Mont Blanc for summer 2026! Here's my preparation timeline:

**12 Months Out (Now)**:
- Research routes (clockwise vs counter-clockwise)
- Start fitness training
- Set budget (~€2000 including flights)

**9 Months Out**:
- Book flights to Geneva
- Reserve mountain refuges (they fill up fast!)
- Gear check - test everything on weekend trips

**6 Months Out**:
- Intensive training (long weekend hikes with full pack)
- Break in new boots
- Learn basic French/Italian phrases

**3 Months Out**:
- Finalize daily itinerary
- Train at elevation if possible
- Get travel insurance

**1 Month Out**:
- Final gear shakedown
- Meal planning
- Download offline maps

**Training Focus**:
- Back-to-back long days (TMB is 11 days straight!)
- Hill repeats with weighted pack
- Recovery protocols

I'll document the whole journey - follow along!
